message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of popliteal and pedal pulses on the right suggests an acute arterial occlusion. A CT angiogram is ordered for further evaluation, but before the procedure, the patient should receive normal saline to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer normal saline (C). Administering mannitol (A) may be used for reducing intracranial pressure, and administering ionic contrast (B) may be used for imaging studies, but these are not the immediate management for an arterial occlusion. Administering sodium bicarbonate (D) may be used to treat metabolic acidosis, but this is not indicated in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely diagnosis is acute arterial occlusion due to atherosclerosis in the peripheral arteries. A CT angiogram is ordered to confirm this diagnosis. Before the test, the patient needs hydration with normal saline to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy, and therefore option (C) is the most appropriate next step in management. Administration of mannitol or sodium bicarbonate is not necessary for this situation. Option (B) is incorrect because it is contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency, which is suggested by the elevated creatinine level in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate next step is to administer normal saline to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy, as a CT angiogram with contrast is ordered. Mannitol is used to decrease intracranial pressure, ionic contrast can cause nephropathy, and sodium bicarbonate is used to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy but is not the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is suspected of having an acute arterial embolism with absent distal pulses. Administration of normal saline is the most appropriate next step as it helps maintain intravascular volume and prevent hypotension. Mannitol and ionic contrast are not appropriate at this stage and sodium bicarbonate may be used later to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CT angiogram requires the use of contrast material, and normal saline is the most appropriate option for hydration and contrast administration. Mannitol is used for cerebral edema, and sodium bicarbonate is used to manage acid-base disturbances or prevent contrast-induced nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with acute limb ischemia and the next step in management is to administer normal saline to rehydrate the patient and improve blood flow. Mannitol and sodium bicarbonate are used for specific indications and do not address the acute ischemia. Ionic contrast is contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency, which this patient has.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing acute limb ischemia, as evidenced by the sudden severe pain and absent pulses on the right. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer normal saline to maintain intravascular volume, as this can help maintain patency of existing collaterals and improve perfusion to the ischemic limb. Administering mannitol, ionic contrast, or sodium bicarbonate would not be the appropriate next step in management of acute limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with acute limb ischemia, likely caused by atherosclerosis. The most appropriate step in management is to administer normal saline to maintain adequate hydration and support organ perfusion until revascularization can occur. Mannitol, ionic contrast, and sodium bicarbonate are not indicated in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing acute limb ischemia, which requires emergent treatment to restore blood flow to the affected limb. Administering normal saline can help increase intravascular volume and improve perfusion to the tissues. Mannitol is a diuretic and can worsen hypovolemia, while ionic contrast can be harmful to patients with impaired kidney function like this patient. Sodium bicarbonate is used in the treatment of metabolic acidosis and has no role in the management of acute limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute limb ischemia, which requires immediate revascularization. Administration of normal saline can help maintain hydration and blood pressure, which are important in acute limb ischemia. Administering mannitol or sodium bicarbonate can be useful in other situations, such as cerebral edema or metabolic acidosis, respectively. Administering ionic contrast would be useful during the CT angiogram, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management.
